description: From Middle English fling, from the verb (see below). Compare Icelandic flengur (“a fast sprint”).

entries.meaning: An act of throwing, often violently.
An act of moving the limbs or body with violent movements, especially in a dance.
An act or period of unrestrained indulgence.
examples: When I was as young as you, I had my fling. I led a life of pleasure.

entries.meaning: A short romantic, oftentimes sexual, relationship.
examples: I had a fling with a girl I met on holiday.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) An attempt, a try (as in "give it a fling").
(obsolete) A severe or contemptuous remark; an expression of sarcastic scorn; a gibe or taunt.
examples: I, who love to have a fling, / Both at senate house and king.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A trifling matter; an object of contempt.
examples: England were but a fling / Save for the crooked stick and the grey goose wing.

description: From Middle English flyngen, from Old Norse flengja (“to whip”), from Proto-Germanic *flangijaną (“to beat, whip”), from Proto-Indo-European *pleh₂k- (“to beat”). Cognate with Icelandic flengja (“to spank”), Norwegian flengja (“to rip, tear, or fling open”).

verbs.description: fling (third-person singular simple present flings, present participle flinging, simple past flung or (colloquial or dialectal, nonstandard) flang or (nonstandard) flinged, past participle flung or (nonstandard) flinged)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, now archaic) To move (oneself) abruptly or violently; to rush or dash.
examples: "We beseech your Majesty—" said Glozelle, but Miraz had flung out of the tent and they could hear him bawling out his acceptance to Edmund.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To throw with violence or quick movement; to hurl.
(intransitive, archaic) To throw; to wince; to flounce.
examples: The horse flung most potently, making his heels fly aloft in the air.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To utter abusive language; to sneer.
examples: The scold began to flout and fling.
